description:
Attested in the 15th Century C.E.; from Middle English separacioun, from Old French separacion, from Latin separatio, separationem.
Morphologically separate +â€Ž -ion

entries.meaning: The act of disuniting two or more things, or the condition of being separated.
examples: Synonyms: detachment, disjunction, division, rupture, severance; see also Thesaurus:separation
Antonyms: annexation, combination, unification; see also Thesaurus:junction

entries.meaning: The act or condition of two or more people being separated from one another.

definitionGroups.group: The act or condition of a married couple living in separate homes while remaining legally married.

entries.meaning: (law) An agreement legalizing such an arrangement.
examples: Synonym: divorce from bed and board

entries.meaning: The place at which a division occurs.
An interval, gap or space that separates things or people.
examples: Synonyms: break, interstice; see also Thesaurus:interspace

entries.meaning: An object that separates two spaces.
(military) Departure from active duty, while not necessarily leaving the service entirely.
